metadata.title: B.S. in Data Science… Is it worth majoring in it? (ft. My DS Coursework) | by Jaemin Lee | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: B.S. in Data Science… Is it worth majoring in it? (ft. My DS Coursework)
metadata.description: Data science is an emerging field, and numerous colleges and universities are offering undergraduate data science programs nowadays. As a recent graduate with a B.S. in Data Science who landed a job…

all_paragraphs: Data science is an emerging field, and numerous colleges and universities are offering undergraduate data science programs nowadays.

As a recent graduate with a B.S. in Data Science who landed a job in the data science field, I would like to talk about my school’s data science coursework and if they benefitted me or not. I would also like to share my opinion on whether it’s worth majoring in data science as an undergraduate.
I was one of the first two (just my friend and I, literally) to graduate with a B.S. in Data Science at my university and I had a very interesting experience with the program.

I was a CS major up until the first semester of my junior (3rd) year (Fall 2018). During that semester, I got into stock trading and I came across building predictive models for stock prices. The idea of using the data to predict stock prices was fascinating to me and I discovered the field of data science.
Interestingly, my university announced that they are going to offer a data science program the following semester, and the coursework they listed excited me.

In spring 2019, I officially switched my major from CS to DS. However, I was in a very interesting situation. Some of the upper-level classes weren’t ready to be taught and my school didn’t expect that there would be a student who’s close to graduating to switch his major. Those classes were Big Data and Deep Learning courses.

I remember my advisor reaching out to the dean of the CS department to explain the situation I was in and it was such a hassle to find a professor who could instruct those two classes. They finally were able to find a professor who could teach them for the next semester (fall 2019).

In fall 2019, we found out that the professor was suffering from a serious chronic illness and he couldn’t teach that semester (during the semester we heard that he passed away. Rest in peace, Dr. Semper). So, we had to find other available professors who could teach those two courses. Long story short, I was put in an executive graduate class (professionals in the industry that are pursuing Master’s degrees) for big data and I had to meet with a professor at his office to take the deep learning course.

Fall 2019 will be one of the most memorable semesters. There were quite a lot of hiccups, in the beginning, but during that semester I took all the useful courses that helped me in my data science journey — machine learning, deep learning, statistical learning, big data, and probability.
** Special thanks to my advisor, Rick, for going out of his way to help me navigate through my college journey. Your guinea pig will continue to grow!**
The data science program at my university was a mixture of CS, stats, and math.

Overall, I am very satisfied with the courses that my school offered. All the programming classes were project-based, rather than theory-based, so I feel I learned a lot. Doing hands-on projects is much more helpful in gaining practical skills. Also, the knowledge I gained from taking stats courses was definitely helpful in getting a job.

Thus, I would check the syllabi of your courses and see if they are project-based or not. During my interview process, I learned that employers don’t care how you got the knowledge. They care whether you can solve real-world problems or not. The more projects you do, the better you will be at problem-solving.

So… is it worth pursuing a B.S. in Data Science? It really depends on what your school offers. As I mentioned above, I would go through the degree plan and check the descriptions of the coursework and syllabi and make sure if you can really learn from the courses (a.k.a. project-based classes). Here are some takeaways:
I believe your knowledge and skills outweigh your degree. If you are an undergraduate who wants to get into the data science field, focus on what you can get out of from your courses!
I hope you find this article useful. Thank you for reading it!
